results.title: Hunter
results.brief_description: In this 2D hand-drawn animation The Hunter, the animator uses stereotypical images (remniscent of the 50’s hollywood animation)of a tribal African wandering through the desert in search of a party. Whilst wearing shoes made from coconuts the man puts a bucket on his head and is then shot by a hunter.

results.title: The Grievance hearing
results.creator_credit: Art Babbitt, Edward L. Gershman and Academy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
A case study of a grievance, to show how hearings are conducted, what their purposes are and how a willingness to compromise can settle most disputes. In the case shows, a worker out sick for several weeks, has forgotten to notify the company formally of her illness. Under the collective bargaining contract this constitutes an “automatic quit”. Wen the worker returns she finds that her job has been filled. On the basis of her good working record, her three years’ seniority , and the nature of her illness - an operation that prevented her from calling in - the Sop Steward files a grievance. A hearing is held, attended by the Committee Chairman and other members of the Union, the Manager, a Personnel Man, and Mary, the worker. The Company agrees to re-hire Mary, placing her where they can find room; the union agrees that this will not constitute a precedent.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Art Babbitt, Edward L. Gershman and Academy Productions

results.title: Employment interview
results.creator_credit: Art Babbitt, C Moray Foutz and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
The importance of the employment interview in getting the right person on the job. A brief review of poor hiring methods is given to illustrate how good workers can be overlooked in favour of less qualified, more aggressive, workers when those who do the hiring are untrained or indifferent. The film then illustrates a good interview, step by step; obtaining information through application forms and friendly discussion, testing, use of rating scale, etc. The function of foreman and supervisors in the interview is discussed, and pre-induction preparation of the applicant hired is shown.

results.title: The Greatest story untold
results.brief_description: A short animation using both 3D claymation and 2D hand-drawn animation. A caveman wanders through the snow back to his cave and family after a hunt to find his family telling their dreams of the future. The stories differ with visions of our contemporary life, aliens kidnapping humans, and battles between good and evil.

results.title: Communications
results.creator_credit: Art Babbitt, C Fouty and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
Shows the need for effective communication in industry, not only in sales and production operations, but also in matters concerning the whole plant and its personnel. In the absence of authoritative information, rumours flourish sometimes causing serious tension among personnel, as illustrated in this film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Art Babbitt, C Fouty and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: The Fang
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The Fang is an animation that uses the animated contributions of past AIM students. Produced and directed by Al MacInnes with the song performed by his band Dan and Al, the Fang celebrates and displays the vast animation techniques and styles used by Al’s peers. The Fang himself is a character around town who wonders what the fang is and discovers that he is the fang, a very much sort after man.

results.title: Darn tootin'
results.brief_description: A 2D hand-drawn animation, ‘Darn tootin’ is a spoof on the masculiny of cowboys depicted in Westerns. The animation has many mixed references…An American accented cowboy rides into town and says hello to a cross-dressing Aussie accented blacksmith. Another American cowboy asks him for a drink, the two walk hand in hand into the saloon (USA pub) bearing a sign reading No Singlets, No thongs (an Australian reference). The foley used throughout places the ‘Western’ town in Australia with the sounds of Australian birds.

results.title: All ears
results.creator_credit: Ben McGill, David Atkinson, Robyn Blake, Bruce McGill, Jeane McGill, Jeremy Parker and Sunny McGill
results.brief_description: A short claymation about an old man whose quiet ‘memory filled’ days are rudely interrupted by a pushy salesman. As the old man contently potters around his flat faintly hearing the outside world he is bombarded by the overbearing hard-sell tactics of a salesman selling hearing aids.

results.title: The Harder they come [DVD]
results.brief_description: The first independent feature film produced in Jamaica gave many Americans their first taste of reggae music with musician Jimmy Cliff in the title role, backed by a fabulous reggae soundtrack. Cliff plays Ivan, a naive rural singer who moves to the city in search of fame but is soon impoverished and exploited by the music industry before becoming embroiled in the trade of marijuana and murder; simultaneously Ivan’s music is released to great acclaim and he becomes somewhat of a local anti-hero. As well as offering a unique view of the reggae scene the milieu of this film also offers a de-romanticised view of seedy Kingston life. Indeed Henzell’s style borders on documentary, as he evokes the squalor of the street, the impoverishment of the people and the multi-faceted systemic corruption. Soundtrack includes the title track as well as other reggae hits “You Can Really Get It if You Want It”, “Sitting in Limbo” and “Johnny Too Bad”. Cast includes Basil Keane, Ras Daniel Hartman, Winston Stona, Janet Barkley, Bobby Charlton and Carl Bradshaw.

results.title: The Happy prince
results.brief_description:
Based on an abridged version of the well-known story of “The Happy prince” by Irish writer Oscar Wilde. It tells of the efforts of a statue, the Happy Prince, to bring relief from poverty to the people in his town with the assistance of a dedicated swallow.
This digital video was made with a class of grade 6 students in a small village school in Dromohaire, County Leitrim, Ireland in late 2003-2004, and directed and edited by Michael Buckley. Sue McCauley was creative producer.
The production combined fine art practices and theatrical improvisation with digital media. The whole work was shot in the classroom at the school with backgrounds and animation added through compositing technique to create a visual richness through multi-layering of the imagery. The vision for the project was to make a work for an audience of children, primarily by children using a theatrical, ensemble, improvisational technique. Funded by the Australian Council for the Arts.
